results.title: Black Dahlia
results.brief_description:
Black Dahlia is a suspense thriller based loosely on the unsolved California murder of Elizabeth Short, nicknamed “Black Dahlia” for her favoritism towards black clothing.

The game is a point-and-click puzzle-solving adventure with live action cutscenes. Full 360 degree horizontal and limited vertical panning allow the player to scan each scene with the mouse. Jim’s in-game notebook acts as a journal as it records everything of importance that he has examined.

Black Dahlia has over sixty puzzles dispersed over nearly as many locations. They range in difficulty, style and type including jigsaw, manipulation, code breaking, mazes and object based. Well publicized bypass codes can be used to “auto-solve” them without compromising the game, since no score is kept.

constellations_other.name: Women and crime
constellations_other.description: The allure and fascination of dangerous women and women in danger.

results.description: Taking place in the 1940s, the game puts the player in control of a rookie government agent, Jim Pearson, whose first case involves investigating Nazi propaganda. The case is not as simple as it sounds, however. Before long, Jim uncovers information and evidence that the Nazis have connections to the supernatural, occultism as well as some very bizarre and ritualistic killings. Jim meets Elizabeth Short who possesses a strange engraved stone known as the “Black Dahlia”, an artifact coveted by the Nazis as a source of ultimate power. When her brutal murder occurs, the stone disappears. During Jim’s search for the missing item, he uncovers a web of evil, deceit and intrigue. Will he get out alive .. and uncorrupted?

results.title: Black cloud over Bali
results.brief_description: In March 1963, Bali’s holy mountain, Gurung Agung, erupted. Over a wide area there was darkness and rain and thousands fled their homes. Molten lava poured down the mountainside killing 1,500 people; 189,000 acres of rice paddy fields were destroyed and a wide area was covered in volcanic ash. Narrated by Denis Mathews.

results.title: Black chicks talking [Widescreen] (A)
results.creator_credit: BungaburBungabura Productions, SBS Independent, Bain Stewart and Leah Purcell
results.brief_description: Performer and writer Leah Purcell talks with five very different Indigenous women - Rosanna Angus, Kathryn Hay, Deborah Mailman, Cilla Malone and Tammy Williams - about what it means to be Aboriginal in Australia today. In a series of individual interviews and at one lively dinner party, the women frankly share their life experiences and opinions. Though their backgrounds are extremely diverse, common themes of culture, family, racism and denial run through their stories, as does the ongoing personal and social legacy of past government polices of forced removal. The result is a passionate and challenging exploration of black identity. Teachers notes available through Film Australia at: http://www.filmaust.com.au/programs/default.asp?content=teachers_notes

results.title: Black cat, white cat
results.creator_credit: CiBy 2000, Pandora Films, Komuna, Karl Baumgartner and Emir Kusturica
results.brief_description: Bosnian-born filmmaker, Emir Kusturica, made this farcical comedy set in a Gypsy settlement along the banks of the Danube, where three generations of characters burst forth in manic and frenetic displays of charm, confusion and chaos. The story is built around two old friends and their families who become impossibly entangled in a marriage of inconvenience. With a soundtrack of Gypsy music and songs, the funny film features numerous non-professional in the cast. In Serbo-Croation with English subtitles. Cast includes: Bajram Severdzan, Florijan Ajdini, Salija Ibraimova, Branka Katic and Srdjan Todorovic.

results.title: Black by popular demand: black and blue: black women in jazz and blues music.
results.brief_description: These two documentaries take a traditional approach to familiar subjects and rely for their impact on the strength of the stories they have to tell. ‘Tiny and Ruby: hell divin’ women’ (Producer Andrea Weiss, director Greta Schiller) evokes the masculine milieu of the American jazz scene that two marginalised women have managed to succeed in. ‘Wild women don’t have the blues’ (Producers Carol Doyle Van Vallenburgh) mixes the oral history of now veteran performers with archive footage, old photographs and sound recordings to revise male-oriented preconceptions around development of the blues. Both stories are set against an economic and social context in which black people were far from equal, emphasising the strength, determination and sheer power of women who live on their music. This compilation will appeal not only to those interested in blues and jazz, but is also a good example for cinema studies for it’s documentary, drama and animation style.

results.title: Black books [the complete 1st series]
results.brief_description: In the tradition of hilarious British comedy, “Black books” offers its social insights via a campaign of acerbic one-liners and surreal plot devices. Bernard Black (Dylan Moran) is an Irish expatriate, London bookstore proprietor, and devoted alcoholic. From his introduction in Episode One, ushering customers out of his shop with broom and megaphone, we know these are the antics of the arch-misanthrope of recent television. Joining Bernard is his drinking partner Fran (Tamsin Greig) and Manny (Bill Bailey), a hairy if naive newcomer to the absurd business practices of Black Books. These first six episodes are a fine solution to the stodgy formula of popular US comedy.

results.title: Black berries
results.creator_credit: AFTRS, Ema Mulholland and Rosie Travers
results.brief_description:
Black Berries is a story about Candy and Lao, two 12 year old best friends. One fateful day while walking home, the girls come to a laneway - the short cut. Lao begins to walk down it but, in a moment of loyalty, Candy keeps a promise she made to her mother and chooses the long way home.
Cast includes Anne Louise Lambert.

results.title: Black belt Jones
results.creator_credit: Warner Bros Pictures, Fred Weintraub, Paul Heller and Robert Clouse
results.brief_description: Pop Boyd (Scatman Crothers) owns a thriving karate school near downtown Los Angeles. Unfortunately it sits on a piece of land upon which the local mob wants to build its own ‘civic centre’. When the gangsters’ muscling of Pop leads to tragedy, Black Belt Jones (Jim Kelly) steps forward to exact his own brand of lightning-charged revenge. Filmmaker Robert Crouse, who showcased Bruce Lee in ‘Enter the dragon’ and Jackie Chan in ‘The big brawl’, serves up masterful action sequences in which every move is choreographed like a ballet. Cast also includes Gloria Hendry, Eric Laneuville, Alan Weeks, Andre Philippe and Vincent Barbi. See also ‘Game of death’ (1978), ‘Enter the dragon’ (1973), ‘The big brawl’ (1980).

results.title: Black Beauty
results.brief_description: Animated version of the classic novel by Anna Sewell. Black Beauty has a good start in life. He is raised in the scenic English countryside, is taught by his mother to be a friend to man, and has a good master, Squire Gordon, and stableman, John Manley. Beauty’s view of the world is tarnished by Ginger, the mare who shares the stable, who is bitter and disappointed with mankind and urges Beauty to believe her sentiments. When Beauty is sold it appears that Ginger was right, as his new owners treat him as a job horse. It is only through Black Beauty’s courage and faith, instilled in him through his upbringing that Beauty learns to appreciate mankind again. Features the voices of David Gregory, Laurie Mann, Mike Evans and Barbara Stevens.

results.title: Black Beauty
results.creator_credit: Tigon Pictures, Chilton Film Productions, Tony Tenser and James Hill
results.brief_description: Adapted by Wolf Mankowitz from the classic children’s book by Anna Sewell, Black Beauty tells the story of a luckless horse who is passed from hand to hand but is finally restored to its original young master and has a happy retirement. Stars Mark Lester, Walter Slezak and Patrick Mower.
